comment: Much stronger is 2 ... d5. This gets a foothold in the center, opens up a line for your bishop on c8, and to boot forces white to move one of his pieces again, since the Rook on h3 is threatened by black's bishop. Notice too, that now the g5 square is open for white's pieces, since now your h-pawn can't cover it.

comment: Since a rook is worth more than a bishop (rook = 5 pawns, bishop = 3 pawns), better is to take the free material with ...Bxh3. Believe it or not, among masters, the difference of having a rook instead of a bishop is winning.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, as it highlights the superior value of the rook over the bishop and suggests capturing the bishop with the rook to gain a material advantage.

This move could easily be exploited, as having a rook instead of a bishop can make a big difference in the game."
